sen.j: 公卿（くぎょう）とは公家の中でも日本の律令の規定に基づく太政官の最高幹部として国政を担う職位、すなわち太政大臣・左大臣・右大臣・大納言・中納言・参議ら（もしくは従三位以上）の高官（総称して議政官という）を差す用語である。
sen.e: "Kugyo" is a term referring to court noble posts responsible for national politics as the top-ranking officers of Daijokan (Department of State) based on provisions of Japanese ritsuryo, namely, the top officials (collectively called giseikan), Daijodaijin (Chancellor of State), Sadaijin (minister of the left), Udaijin (minister of the right), Dainagon (chief councilor of state), Chunagon (Middle Counselor), and Sangi (imperial advisor) (or Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) or higher).

"Kugyo" is a term referring to court noble posts responsible for national politics as the top-ranking officers of Daijokan (Department of State) based on provisions of Japanese ritsuryo, namely, the top officials (collectively called giseikan), Daijodaijin (Chancellor of State), Sadaijin (minister of the left), Udaijin (minister of the right), Dainagon (chief councilor of state), Chunagon (Middle Counselor), and Sangi (imperial advisor) (or Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) or higher).

"Kugyo" is a term referring to court noble posts responsible for national politics as the top-ranking officers of Daijokan (Grand Council of State) based on provisions of the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code), namely, the top officials (collectively called giseikan), Daijo-daijin (Grand minister of state), Sadaijin (minister of the left), Udaijin (minister of the right), Dainagon (chief councilor of state), Chunagon (vice-councilor of state), and Sangi (imperial advisor) (or Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) or higher).

sen.j: 武家政治が成立し、官職の僭称（勝手に名乗ること）がまかり通るようになると武家官位、百官名、東百官という官職を模倣した名乗りが成立するようになる（もちろん、徳川将軍家や徳川御三家などは武家でありながら従三位以上に昇って公卿の資格を得ている）。
sen.e: When the military rule was established and pretension of government services went unchallenged, bukekani (military court rank), hyakkanna (court rank-like names used by warriors), and azumahyakkan (court rank-like names used by warriors in the Kanto region), which are identification imitating those for government services were established (Needless to say, the Tokugawa Shogun family and the three families of the Tokugawas were promoted to Jusanmi or higher to qualify for kugyo despite being military families).

sen.j: ちなみに貴族の敬称としては太政大臣、左大臣、右大臣、内大臣の名の下に氏の下に朝臣、名の下に公とつけて敬称し、三位以上の貴人や参議の官にある者に対しては氏の下に朝臣、名の下に卿とつけて敬称した。
sen.e: As the title of honor for kizoku (noble), ason was added after the family name and ko was added after the first name for Daijodaijin, Sadaijin, Udaijin, Naidaijin (inner minister), and for kizoku or Sangi official of third rank or higher, ason was added after the family name and kyo was added after the first name to honor them.

sen.j: 平安時代末期より公家の中で摂家が確立するに至り、貴族の格式、家格が固まってくると公卿になれるのは源氏・平氏・藤原氏・橘氏のいわゆる源平藤橘の四姓だけになった（後に菅原氏・阿倍氏・賀茂氏なども嫡流に限って認められた）。
sen.e: When sekke (regent families) was established among court nobles beginning at the end of the Heian period, and the social status and family status became fixed, the so called genpeitokitsu, or the Minamoto clan, Taira clan, Fujiwara clan, and Tachibana clan, became the only four family names allowed to become kugyo (Later, Sugawara clan, Abe clan, and Kamo clan were allowed, but limited to those in the lineage of eldest son).
